member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.OcrSession.VerifyText(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.String)
member.summary: Verifies the accuracy of the text in the image. For each character, the method checks for the existence of a reference character for the expected character class and compares the character from the image to the reference character.
member.param: The source image for this operation.
The expected character values in the image.
member.returns: A collection of verification scores for the patterns in the image. If a reference character does not exist for the character class of a character, the method sets the score corresponding to that character to 0.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.OcrSession.VerifyText(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.String,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi)
member.summary: Verifies the accuracy of the text in the image. For each character, the method checks for the existence of a reference character for the expected character class and compares the character from the image to the reference character.
member.param: The source image for this operation.
The expected character values in the image.

The ROI that the method performs this operation on. Pass null or Nothing to use the entire image for this operation. If the ROI has multiple contours, each contour is interpreted as a character in the image. If the ROI only has one contour, the method searches the ROI for text.
member.returns: A collection of verification scores for the patterns in the image. If a reference character does not exist for the character class of a character, the method sets the score corresponding to that character to 0.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.OcrSession.VerifyPatterns(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.String[])
member.summary: Verifies the accuracy of the text in the image. For each pattern, the method checks for the existence of a reference character for the expected character class and compares the character from the image to the reference character.
member.param: The source image for this operation.
The array of expected patterns in the image.
member.returns: A collection of verification scores for the patterns in the image. If a reference character does not exist for the character class of a character, the method sets the score corresponding to that character to 0.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.OcrSession.VerifyPatterns(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.String[],NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi)
member.summary: Verifies the accuracy of the text in the image. For each pattern, the method checks for the existence of a reference character for the expected character class and compares the character from the image to the reference character.
member.param: The source image for this operation.
The array of expected patterns in the image.

The ROI that the method performs this operation on. Pass null or Nothing to use the entire image for this operation. If the ROI has multiple contours, each contour is interpreted as a pattern location in the image. If the ROI only has one contour, the method searches the ROI for the expected patterns.
member.returns: A collection of verification scores for the patterns in the image. If a reference character does not exist for the character class of a character, the method sets the score corresponding to that character to 0.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.ColorClassifierSession.SupervisedColorSegmentation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Segments a color image using trained samples.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Label Image is a reference to the label image.
member.returns: Collection of ROILabel objects.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.ColorClassifierSession.SupervisedColorSegmentation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32)
member.summary: Segments a color image using trained samples.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Label Image is a reference to the label image.

Maximum Distance is the maximum allowed color distance to group the pixel windows. Valid values are 0 to 1000. A value of 0 represents a conservative search strategy and a value of 1000 represents an aggressive search strategy.
member.returns: Collection of ROILabel objects.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.ColorClassifierSession.SupervisedColorSegmentation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Segments a color image using trained samples.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Label Image is a reference to the label image.

Maximum Distance is the maximum allowed color distance to group the pixel windows. Valid values are 0 to 1000. A value of 0 represents a conservative search strategy and a value of 1000 represents an aggressive search strategy.
Min Identification Score is the minimum identification score required to group the pixel. Valid values are 0 to 1000.
member.returns: Collection of ROILabel objects.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.ColorClassifierSession.SupervisedColorSegmentation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Collections.ObjectModel.Collection{NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.ROILabel})
member.summary: Segments a color image using trained samples.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Label Image is a reference to the label image.

Maximum Distance is the maximum allowed color distance to group the pixel windows. Valid values are 0 to 1000. A value of 0 represents a conservative search strategy and a value of 1000 represents an aggressive search strategy.
Min Identification Score is the minimum identification score required to group the pixel. Valid values are 0 to 1000.
Labels In is a Collection of ROILabel class objects having class names and labels that you want to segment.
member.returns: Collection of ROILabel objects.

member.summary: Segments a color image using trained samples.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Label Image is a reference to the label image.

Maximum Distance is the maximum allowed color distance to group the pixel windows. Valid values are 0 to 1000. A value of 0 represents a conservative search strategy and a value of 1000 represents an aggressive search strategy.
Min Identification Score is the minimum identification score required to group the pixel. Valid values are 0 to 1000.
Labels In is a Collection of ROILabel class objects having class names and labels that you want to segment.
Specifies the parameters used to configure the color segmentation algorithm.
member.returns: Collection of ROILabel objects.

member.summary: Segments a color image using trained samples.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Label Image is a reference to the label image.

Maximum Distance is the maximum allowed color distance to group the pixel windows. Valid values are 0 to 1000. A value of 0 represents a conservative search strategy and a value of 1000 represents an aggressive search strategy.
Min Identification Score is the minimum identification score required to group the pixel. Valid values are 0 to 1000.
Labels In is a Collection of ROILabel class objects having class names and labels that you want to segment.
Specifies the parameters used to configure the color segmentation algorithm.

Specifies the region of interest specifying the location of the sample in the image. The ROI must be one or more closed contours. If ROI Descriptor is empty or not connected, the entire image is considered to be the region.
member.returns: Collection of ROILabel objects.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.TextureDefectClassifierSession.DetectTextureDefect(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Char,System.Double)
member.summary: Detects defects in textured images.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Image Dst is a reference to the destination image.

Initial Step Size specifies the offset, in pixels, by which the classifier should reposition the window during the initial defect detection phase. Values range from 0 to the smallest window dimension. The default value of 0 indicates no overlap between windows. A small, non-zero step size processes the image in more detail, but increases the time required to process the image.

Final Step Size specifies the offset, in pixels, by which the classifier should reposition the window during the final detect detection phase. The default value of 1 indicates that the classifier will reposition the window by 1 pixel as it searches for defects.The window is positioned only on pixels detected as defects in the initial defect detection phase. A smaller, non-zero step size processes the image in more detail, but increases the time required to process the image. This value must be smaller than the Initial Step Size if the Initial Step Size is set to a value greater than zero.
Defect Pixel Value is the value used to replace defect pixels in the image.

Min. Defect Identification Score is the value used to determine if a pixel in the image is a defect. The pixel is classified as a defect if the identification score is greater than or equal to this value.
member.returns: Nothing.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8, U16 and I16 images.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.TextureDefectClassifierSession.DetectTextureDefect(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Char,System.Double,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi)
member.summary: Detects defects in textured images.
member.param: Image Src is a reference to the source image.
Image Dst is a reference to the destination image.

Initial Step Size specifies the offset, in pixels, by which the classifier should reposition the window during the initial defect detection phase. Values range from 0 to the smallest window dimension. The default value of 0 indicates no overlap between windows. A small, non-zero step size processes the image in more detail, but increases the time required to process the image.

Final Step Size specifies the offset, in pixels, by which the classifier should reposition the window during the final detect detection phase. The default value of 1 indicates that the classifier will reposition the window by 1 pixel as it searches for defects.The window is positioned only on pixels detected as defects in the initial defect detection phase. A smaller, non-zero step size processes the image in more detail, but increases the time required to process the image. This value must be smaller than the Initial Step Size if the Initial Step Size is set to a value greater than zero.
Defect Pixel Value is the value used to replace defect pixels in the image.

Min. Defect Identification Score is the value used to determine if a pixel in the image is a defect. The pixel is classified as a defect if the identification score is greater than or equal to this value.
ROI Descriptor specifies the region of the image in which to detect defects.
member.returns: Nothing.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8, U16 and I16 images.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.AbsoluteDifference(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Subtracts one image from another and returns the absolute value of the difference.
member.param: The first input image.
The second input image.
The resulting image. The destination image can be one of the source images.
member.remarks:
Use this method with image types U8, I16, Sgl, and Rgb32. The image type of sourceB depends on the image type of sourceA, as follows:
If sourceA is U8, sourceB must be U8, I16, Sgl, or Rgb.
If sourceA is I16 or Sgl, sourceB must be U8, I16, or Sgl.
If sourceA is Rgb, sourceB must be Rgb or U8.
If sourceB is of an image type that contains more bits per pixel than sourceA, sourceB and destination must be the same type of image. Otherwise, sourceA and destination must be the same type of image. This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
' Find the absolute difference between the image in i and the image ' in imageViewer1 ' Do the operation inplace (store the result in i) Algorithms.AbsoluteDifference(imageViewer1.Image, i, i)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.AbsoluteDifference(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.PixelValue,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Subtracts a constant from an image and returns the absolute value of the difference.
member.param: The input image.
The pixel value.
The resulting image. The destination image can be one of the source images.
member.remarks: Use this method with image types U8, I16, Sgl, and Rgb32. The destination image and source image must be the same type of image. This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
' Add a constant to an image in imageViewer1. ' Store the result in i Algorithms.AbsoluteDifference(imageViewer1.Image, New PixelValue(50), i)

If sourceA is I16 or Sgl, sourceB must be U8, I16, or Sgl.
If sourceA is Rgb32, sourceB must be Rgb32 or U8.
If sourceB is of an image type that contains more bits per pixel than sourceA, sourceB and destination must be the same type of image. Otherwise, sourceA and destination must be the same type of image. This method is optimized for MMX.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Divide(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.param: The first input image.
The second input image.
The resulting image. It can be one of the source images.
member.remarks:
Use this method with image types U8, I16, and Single. The image type of sourceB depends on the image type of sourceA, as follows:
If sourceA is a U8 image, sourceB must be a U8 image.
If sourceA is an I16 image, sourceB must be a U8 or I16 image.
If sourceA is an Single image, sourceB must be a U8, I16, or Single image.
If sourceB is of an image type that contains more bits per pixel than sourceA, sourceB and destination must be the same type of image. Otherwise, sourceA and destination must be the same type of image.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
' Divide the image in Viewer1 by a constant ' Store the result in i Algorithms.Divide (imageViewer1.Image, New PixelValue(50), i)
' Divide the image in Viewer1 by the image in i ' Do the division inplace (store the result in i) Algorithms.Divide (imageViewer1.Image, i, i)

member.summary: Divides an image by an image or a constant.
member.param: The input image.
The pixel value to divide the image by.

member.remarks: Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images. source and destination must be the same type of image. You cannot divide an image by zero. If you set value to 0, the method automatically replaces it with 1.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Max(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Computes the maximum of the pixel values of two images and copies the larger pixel value into the destination pixel.
member.param: The first source image.
The second source image, which must be the same type of image as sourceA.
The destination image.
member.remarks:
Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.
This method copies the larger pixel value of the two source pixels into the destination for each pixel.
If sourceB is of a type that contains more bits per pixel than sourceA, sourceB and destination must be the same type of image. Otherwise, sourceA and destination must be the same type of image.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Find the max of the pixels image i and the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i Algorithms.Max (imageViewer1.Image, i, i)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Max(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.PixelValue,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Computes the maximum of a pixel value and a constant and copies the larger pixel value into the destination pixel.
member.param: The source image.
The pixel value to use in the computation.
The resulting image.
member.remarks:
Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.
This method copies the source image to the destination in the following manner: If the source image pixel value is greater than the given constant, the method copies the source pixel to the destination. Otherwise, the method copies the constant value to the destination.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Find the max of a constant and the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i Algorithms.Max (imageViewer1.Image, New PixelValue (50), i)

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Find the min of the pixels image i and the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i Algorithms.Min (imageViewer1.Image, i, i)

example.code:

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.MultiplyDivide(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Double)
member.summary: Computes a ratio between two source images.
member.param: The first input image.
The second input image.
The resulting image.
The value by which the method multiplies the first image. The default is 255.
member.remarks:
Use this method with U8, I16, Single, and Rgb32 images. All images must be the same type.
The method finds the ratio by multiplying each pixel value in the first source image by a constant. The method divides the result of the multiplication by the corresponding pixel in the second source image. The final result is stored in the destination image.
You can use this method to correct a background if the background is lighter than the image. In a background correction, the first source image is the acquired image and the second source image is the background image.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Perform a MultiplyDivide operation using the images on Viewer1 and Viewer2. 'Store the result in i Algorithms.MultiplyDivide (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer2.Image, i, 30)
'Perform a MultiplyDivide operation using the images on Viewer1 and i. 'Store the result in i Algorithms.MultiplyDivide (imageViewer1.Image, i, i, 10)

If sourceA is U8, sourceB must be U8.

If sourceA is Single, sourceB must be Single, I16, or U8.

This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:

'Subtract image i from the image in Viewer1 'Do the subtraction in-place (store the result in i) Algorithms.Subtract (imageViewer1.Image, i, i)

member.summary: Finds edges along concentric circular or angular paths in the image. Edges are determined based on their contrast and slope.
member.param: The input image.
Describes the bounding annular region within which the concentric paths are defined.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
'This example assumes that you have an annulus selected on the viewer. 'Only look for the first rising edge. Dim EdgeOptions As New EdgeOptions(EdgePolaritySearchMode.Rising) Dim Report As ConcentricRakeReport Report = Algorithms.ConcentricRake(imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Roi, ConcentricRakeDirection.Clockwise, EdgeProcess.First, 5, EdgeOptions) 'Overlay the search arcs For Each arcInfo As SearchArcInfo In Report.SearchArcs imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.[Default].AddArc(arcInfo.Arc) Next 'Overlay the points found on the image. For Each EdgeInfo As EdgeInfo In Report.FirstEdges imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.[Default].AddOval(New OvalContour(EdgeInfo.Position.X - 2, EdgeInfo.Position.Y - 2, 5, 5), Rgb32Value.RedColor, DrawingMode.PaintValue) Next

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.DetectPeaksOrValleys(System.Double[],NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.PeakOrValley)
member.summary: Finds the location, amplitude, and second derivative of peaks or valleys in the input array.
member.param: The input array.
Determines whether to search for peaks or valleys.
member.returns: A collection of objects about each peak or valley found. On failure, an exception is thrown.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.DetectPeaksOrValleys(System.Double[],NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.PeakOrValley,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.DetectPeaksOrValleysOptions)
member.summary: Finds the location, amplitude, and second derivative of peaks or valleys in the input array.
member.param: The input array.
Determines whether to search for peaks or valleys.
Options the method uses for detecting peaks and valleys.
member.returns: A collection of objects about each peak or valley found. On failure, an exception is thrown.
member.remarks: The method is based on an algorithm that fits a quadratic polynomial to a sequential groups of data points. Set the property in the options property to specify the number of data points to use in the fit. For each peak or valley, the method tests the quadratic fit against the value in the options property. The method ignores peaks with values lower than the Threshold and valleys with troughs higher than Threshold.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports System.Collections.ObjectModel
Private Sub Run_Click() ' This example requires you to draw a region on Viewer1 ' before you execute this piece of code. Dim ProfileReport As RoiProfileReport Dim PeakValleyReport As Collection(Of PeakValleyReportItem) Dim Index As Integer ' Find the profile of the regions on Viewer1. ProfileReport = Algorithms.RoiProfile (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Roi) ' Extract the profile array Dim ProfileData As Collection(Of Double) = ProfileReport.Report.ProfileData Dim ProfileDataArray(ProfileData.Count) As Double ProfileData.CopyTo (ProfileDataArray, 0) ' Find the location, amplitude and, derivatives of the peaks ' along this profile PeakValleyReport = Algorithms.DetectPeaksOrValleys (ProfileDataArray, PeakOrValley.Peaks, New DetectPeaksOrValleysOptions (100, 3)) ' Overlay the points where peaks were found For Each ReportItem As PeakValleyReportItem In PeakValleyReport ' Find the index into the ProfileDataArray where the peak was found. This index corresponds ' to the index of the points in ProfileReport.Pixels Index = Math.Round (ReportItem.Position) ' Draw a circular point at ProfileReport.Pixels(Index) -- the point nearest ' to where the peak was found. Dim Point As PointContour = ProfileReport.Pixels(Index) imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.Default.AddOval (New OvalContour (Point.X - 2, Point.Y - 2, 5, 5), Rgb32Value.GreenColor, DrawingMode.PaintValue) Next End Sub

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.DetectRotation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.PointContour,NationalInstruments.Vision.PointContour,System.Int32)
member.summary: Detects the rotational shift between two images, usually a reference image containing a part at a known orientation and another image containing the part in an unknown orientation.
member.param: The reference image.
The test image.
The center of the circle in the reference image.
The center of the circle in the test image.
The radius of the circle used to detect rotation.
member.returns: A non-zero value that specifies the rotational shift between the reference image and the test image. On failure, an exception is thrown.
member.remarks: Use this method with image types U8, I16, and Single. The method extracts pixel values around a circular region in the reference image and compares these values to the same region in the test image. The algorithm looks for the rotational shift between those two samples.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.DetectRotation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.PointContour,NationalInstruments.Vision.PointContour,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Detects the rotational shift between two images, usually a reference image containing a part at a known orientation and another image containing the part in an unknown orientation.
member.param: The reference image.
The test image.
The center of the circle in the reference image.
The center of the circle in the test image.
The radius of the circle used to detect rotation.

The sampling period, in degrees, of the pixel values extracted from the circular region. The sampling period directly affects the speed of the method. If the sampling period is high (the number of samples along the circular region are few), the processing speed increases at the cost of reduced accuracy in the computed rotational shift. The method generates an error if the sampling period is less than or equal to 0.
member.returns: A non-zero value that specifies the rotational shift between the reference image and the test image. On failure, an exception is thrown.
member.remarks: Use this method with image types U8, I16, and Single. The method extracts pixel values around a circular region in the reference image and compares these values to the same region in the test image. The algorithm looks for the rotational shift between those two samples.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i as New VisionImage Dim testCenter as New PointContour Dim referenceCenter as New PointContour Dim angle as Double
' Load the test image into i
' Set the test and reference centers referenceCenter.Initialize (imageViewer1.Image.Width/2, imageViewer1.Image.Height/2) testCenter.Initialize (i.Width/2, i.Height/2)
' Detect the rotational shift between the image on Viewer1 and i angle = Algorithms.DetectRotation (imageViewer1.Image, i, referenceCenter, testCenter, 10, angle)

' Overlay the found lines on the image. For Each Edge As StraightEdgeReportItem In Report.StraightEdges imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.Default.AddLine(Edge.StraightEdge) Next

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.FindTransformRectangle(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi)
member.summary: Computes a coordinate transform based on the position of an object in a search area of an image. The method uses the location and orientation of the coordinate system it finds to create the reference system of a coordinate transform or to update the measurement system of an existing coordinate transform.
member.param: The image which the method uses to compute the coordinate transform.
Defines the area within which the edge detection is performed.
member.returns: A object containing the axes that were located.
member.remarks:
This method uses the following algorithm. First the method determines the position of the main axis of the coordinate system. It locates the intersection points between a set of parallel search lines, or rake, and the edge of an object. The method determines the intersection points based on their contrast, width, and steepness. The method calculates a best-fit line using the points found. This line defines the main axis of the coordinate system. The method then locates the intersection points between a set of parallel search lines that are perpendicular to the main axis and the edge of the object. It calculates a hit-line to the object from the edge closest to the search area detected and perpendicular to the main axis. This line defines the secondary axis of the coordinate system. The intersection between the main axis and secondary axis is the origin of the coordinate system.
Use this method with U8, I16, Single, Rgb32, Hsl32, RgbU64 images.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.FindTransformRectangles(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi)
member.summary: Computes a coordinate transform based on the position of an object in a search area of an image. The method uses the location and orientation of the coordinate system it finds to create the reference system of a coordinate transform or to update the measurement system of an existing coordinate transform.
member.param: The image which the method uses to compute the coordinate transform.
Defines the area within which the edge detection is performed for the primary axis.
Defines the area within which the edge detection is performed for the secondary axis.
member.returns: A object containing the axes that were located.
member.remarks:
This method uses the following algorithm. First the method determines the position of the main axis of the coordinate system. It locates the intersection points between a set of parallel search lines in the primary rectangle and the edge of an object. The method determines the intersection points based on their contrast, width, and steepness. The method calculates a best-fit line through the points found. This line defines the main axis of the coordinate system. The process is repeated perpendicularly in the secondary rectangle in order to locate the secondary axis. The intersection between the main axis and the secondary axis is the origin of the coordinate system.
Use this method with U8, I16, Single, Rgb32, Hsl32, RgbU64 images.

Specifies how to transform pixel coordinates based on the difference between the reference coordinate system and the measurement coordinate system.
member.returns: A object containing the axes that were located.
member.remarks:
This method uses the following algorithm. First the method determines the position of the main axis of the coordinate system. It locates the intersection points between a set of parallel search lines in the primary rectangle and the edge of an object. The method determines the intersection points based on their contrast, width, and steepness. The method calculates a best-fit line through the points found. This line defines the main axis of the coordinate system. The process is repeated perpendicularly in the secondary rectangle in order to locate the secondary axis. The intersection between the main axis and the secondary axis is the origin of the coordinate system.
Use this method with U8, I16, Single, Rgb32, Hsl32, RgbU64 images.

member.summary: Computes a coordinate transform based on the position of an object in a search area of an image. The method uses the location and orientation of the coordinate system it finds to create the reference system of a coordinate transform or to update the measurement system of an existing coordinate transform.
member.param: The image which the method uses to compute the coordinate transform.
Defines the area within which the edge detection is performed for the primary axis.
Defines the area within which the edge detection is performed for the secondary axis.
Specifies how the method updates the coordinate transform. The default is
Specifies how to transform pixel coordinates based on the difference between the reference coordinate system and the measurement coordinate system.
Specifies options for detecting edges along search lines in the ROI and for overlaying search information.
member.returns: A object containing the axes that were located.
member.remarks:
This method uses the following algorithm. First the method determines the position of the main axis of the coordinate system. It locates the intersection points between a set of parallel search lines in the primary rectangle and the edge of an object. The method determines the intersection points based on their contrast, width, and steepness. The method calculates a best-fit line through the points found. This line defines the main axis of the coordinate system. The process is repeated perpendicularly in the secondary rectangle in order to locate the secondary axis. The intersection between the main axis and the secondary axis is the origin of the coordinate system.
Use this method with U8, I16, Single, Rgb32, Hsl32, RgbU64 images.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
'Set up the ROIs. Dim primaryRoi As New Roi(New Shape() {New RectangleContour(0, 0, 80, 80)}) Dim secondaryRoi As New Roi(New Shape() {New RectangleContour(150, 0, 80, 80)})
'Find the transformation in the image in Viewer1. Dim Report As FindTransformReport = Algorithms.FindTransformRectangles (imageViewer1.Image, primaryRoi, secondaryRoi)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Rake(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.RakeDirection,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.EdgeProcess,System.Int32,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.EdgeOptions)
member.summary: Finds edges along a set of parallel lines defined inside a rectangular region. Edges are determined based on their contrast and slope.
member.param: The image in which to find the edges.
The rectangle or rotated rectangular region within which the edge detection is performed.
Defines the direction along which edges are searched for along the lines. The default is RakeDirection.LeftToRight.
Determines the type of search. The method can return the first edge, both the first and the last edge, all edges, or the best edge found along the paths. The default is All.
Defines the distance, in pixels, between the parallel lines inside the rectangular region. The default is 5.
Defines the characteristics that the method uses to find the edges and the parameters it needs for subpixel analysis of the edges.
member.returns: A object containing information about the detected edges.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8, I16, Single, Rgb32, Hsl32, RgbU64 images. The following image illustrates the rake:

example.code:
[Visual Basic] Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
'This routine assumes that you have a rectangle or rotated rectangle selected on the viewer
'Perform a rake. Find only the first edge along each line Dim Report As RakeReport = Algorithms.Rake (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Roi, RakeDirection.LeftToRight, EdgeProcess.First) 'Overlay the search lines For Each LineInfo As SearchLineInfo In Report.SearchLines imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.Default.AddLine (LineInfo.Line, Rgb32Value.BlueColor) Next 'Overlay edge points found For Each Edge As EdgeInfo In Report.FirstEdges Dim pt As PointContour = Edge.Position imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.Default.AddOval (New OvalContour(pt.X - 2, pt.Y - 2, 5, 5), Rgb32Value.RedColor, DrawingMode.DrawValue) Next

member.param: The image in which to find edges.

member.returns: A collection of PointContour objects containing the coordinates of the edge points.

Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.
You can use this method in conjunction with the method to obtain the PointContours that define the path.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports System.Collections.ObjectModel
'Find the edge coordinates along a path defined by regions 'on Viewer1 and display the coordinates on the image.
'First, find the coordinates of the points along the path 'defined by the regions on Viewer1 Dim Profile As RoiProfileReport = Algorithms.RoiProfile (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Roi)
'Find the edges along the selected path Dim EdgeCoordinates As Collection(Of PointContour) = Algorithms.SimpleEdge (imageViewer1.Image, Profile.Pixels)
'Display the results For Each Pt As PointContour In EdgeCoordinates Dim oval As New OvalContour(Pt.X - 4, Pt.Y - 4, 8, 8) imageViewer1.Image.Overlays.Default.AddOval (oval, Rgb32Value.RedColor, DrawingMode.PaintValue) Next

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Convolute(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Kernel)
member.summary: Applies a linear filter to an image by convolving the image with a filtering kernel.
member.param: The image to process.
The resulting image.
The convolution matrix.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8, I16, and Sgl images. The source and the destination images must be the same type of image. The convolution matrix must have an odd width and height. The source image must have been created with a border capable of using the size of the convolution matrix. A 3 x 3 matrix must have a minimum border of 1, a 5 x 5 matrix must have a minimum border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important. This functions is optimized for MMX.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Convolute(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Kernel,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Applies a linear filter to an image by convolving the image with a filtering kernel.
member.param: The image to process.
The resulting image.
The convolution matrix.

Specifies the region of the source image in which the method applies the convolution. The method applies the convolution to only those source pixels whose corresponding mask pixels are non-zero. Do not set this parameter if you want the method to convolve the entire image.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8, I16, and Sgl images. The source and the destination images must be the same type of image. mask must be a U8 image. The convolution matrix must have an odd width and height. The source image must have been created with a border capable of using the size of the convolution matrix. A 3 x 3 matrix must have a minimum border of 1, a 5 x 5 matrix must have a minimum border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important. This functions is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage Dim k As New Kernel(KernelFamily.Gradient, 3, 2) ' Perform a convolution using a gradient filter on the image in Viewer1. ' Store the result in i. Algorithms.Convolute (imageViewer1.Image, i, k)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Correlate(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Computes the normalized cross correlation between the source image and the template image.
member.param: The source image. The correlation modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least half as large as the larger dimension of the template image.
The template image to correlate against the source.
The resulting 8-bit image containing the cross correlation values normalized to lie in the range [0, 255]. A value of 255 indicates a very high correlation and a value of 0 indicates no correlation.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8 images. This method is optimized for MMX. However, MMX optimization is valid only when the width of the template image is a multiple of 4. Correlation is a time-intensive operation. You can reduce the time required to perform a correlation by keeping the template size small and reducing the search area in the source image using a RectangleContour.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Correlate(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Roi)
member.summary: Computes the normalized cross correlation between the source image and the template image.
member.param: The source image. The correlation modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least half as large as the larger dimension of the template image.
The template image to correlate against the source.
The resulting 8-bit image containing the cross correlation values normalized to lie in the range [0, 255]. A value of 255 indicates a very high correlation and a value of 0 indicates no correlation.

Defines a rectangular region in the source image that is used for the correlation process. This parameter must contain 0 or 1 contours. If it contains 1 contour, it must be a RectangleContour. Correlation is applied to the entire image if RectangleContour.None is passed.

You can reduce the time required to perform a correlation by keeping the template size small and reducing the search area in the source image using a RectangleContour.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.InterlaceCombine(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Combines two field images to create a single frame image.
member.param: The odd field.
The even field.
The resulting combined image.
member.remarks: Use this method with all image types.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
'This example swaps every alternate row in the image on Viewer1 Dim even As New VisionImage Dim odd As New VisionImage
'First separate the even and odd frames of the image on Viewer1. Algorithms.InterlaceSeparate (imageViewer1.Image, odd, even)
'Combine the even and odd frames so that the old odd is 'the new even frame and the old even is the new odd frame. 'Store the result in the image on Viewer1. Algorithms.InterlaceCombine (even, odd, imageViewer1.Image)

member.summary: Separates a frame image into two field images.

The image into which the function places the even field of the frame area.
member.remarks: Use this method with all image types.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
'This example swaps every alternate row in the image on Viewer1 Dim even As New VisionImage Dim odd As New VisionImage
'First separate the even and odd frames of the image on Viewer1. Algorithms.InterlaceSeparate (imageViewer1.Image, odd, even)
'Combine the even and odd frames so that the old odd is 'the new even frame and the old even is the new odd frame. 'Store the result in the image on Viewer1. Algorithms.InterlaceCombine (even, odd, imageViewer1.Image)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.RejectBorder(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Eliminates particles that touch the border of an image.
member.param: The source image. If the image has a border, the method sets all border pixel values to 0.
The resulting image.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
source and destination must be U8 images.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.RejectBorder(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Connectivity)
member.summary: Eliminates particles that touch the border of an image.
member.param: The source image. If the image has a border, the method sets all border pixel values to 0.
The resulting image.

Set this parameter to Connectivity8 to use connectivity-8 to determine whether particles are touching. Set this parameter to Connectivity4 to use connectivity-4 to determine whether particles are touching. The default is Connectivity8. For more information about connectivity, refer to the NI Vision Concepts Help.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
source and destination must be U8 images.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage 'Reject the particles touching the border of the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i. Algorithms.RejectBorder (imageViewer1.Image, i, Connectivity.Connectivity8)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.FillHoles(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Fills holes in particles. The method fills the holes with a pixel value of 1.
member.param: The image containing particles with holes to fill.
The resulting image.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8 images. The method does not fill areas touching the edge of the image that appear to be holes because these areas could be either holes or areas of concavity. This function is optimized for MMX.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.FillHoles(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Connectivity)
member.summary: Fills holes in particles. The method fills the holes with a pixel value of 1.
member.param: The image containing particles with holes to fill.
The resulting image.

Set this parameter to Connectivity8 to use connectivity-8 to determine whether particles are touching. Set this parameter to Connectivity4 to use connectivity-4 to determine whether particles are touching. The default is Connectivity8. For more information about connectivity, refer to the NI Vision Concepts Help.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8 images. The method does not fill areas touching the edge of the image that appear to be holes because these areas could be either holes or areas of concavity. This function is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
' Threshold the image on Viewer1 inplace. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
' Fill the holes in the image on Viewer1 that have connectivity-4 and ' store the result in i. Algorithms.FillHoles (imageViewer1.Image, i, Connectivity.Connectivity4)
' Fill the holes in the image on Viewer1 that have connectivity-8. ' Do this operation in place (Store the result in the image on Viewer1). Algorithms.FillHoles (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, Connectivity.Connectivity8)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.RemoveParticle(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Eliminates or keeps particles resistant to a specified number of erosions. The particles that are kept are exactly the same as those found in the original source image.
member.param: The image in which to remove the particles.
The resulting image.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
Use this method with U8 images.
The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.
This method is optimized for MMX.

A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.
This method is optimized for MMX.

This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage 'Find the particles resistant to 3 erosions in the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i. Algorithms.RemoveParticle (imageViewer1.Image, i, 3) 'Remove all particles with connectivity-4 resistant to 3 erosions in i. member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.GrayMorphology(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.MorphologyMethod)
member.summary: Applies morphological transformations to gray level images.
member.param: The image on which the method performs the morphological operation.
The resulting image.
The type of morphological transformation procedure to use.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images. source and destination must be the same type of image.
This function is optimized for MMX.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.GrayMorphology(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.MorphologyMethod,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.StructuringElement)
member.summary: Applies morphological transformations to gray level images.
member.param: The image on which the method performs the morphological operation.
The resulting image.
The type of morphological transformation procedure to use.
Describes the structuring element applied to the image. The default is 3 x 3.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.
source and destination must be the same type of image. The calculation modifies the border of the source image. The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.
A structuring element must have odd-sized dimensions so that it contains a central pixel. If one of the dimensions for the structuring element is even, the function does not take into account the odd boundary, farthest out on the matrix. For example, if the input structuring element is 6 × 4 (Width = 6 and Height = 4), the actual processing is performed at 5 x 3. Both the sixth line and the fourth row are ignored. The processing speed is correlated with the size of the structuring element. For example, a 3 x 3 structuring element processes nine pixels, and a 5 × 5 structuring element processes 25 pixels.
This function is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage Dim element As New StructuringElement
'Perform a POpen operation on the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i. Algorithms.GrayMorphology (imageViewer1.Image, i, MorphphologyMethod.POpen, element)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.ConvexHull(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Computes the convex envelope for each particle in the source image.
member.param: The image containing the particles whose convex envelopes the method calculates.
The resulting image.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8, I16, and floating point images.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.ConvexHull(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Connectivity)
member.summary: Computes the convex envelope for each particle in the source image.
member.param: The image containing the particles whose convex envelopes the method calculates.
The resulting image.

Set this parameter to Connectivity8 to use connectivity-8 to determine whether particles are touching. Set this parameter to Connectivity4 to use connectivity-4 to determine whether particles are touching. The default is Connectivity8. Refer to the NI Vision Concepts Help for more information about connectivity.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8, I16, and floating point images.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage Dim j As New VisionImage ' Threshold the image in Viewer1 and store the results in i Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, i, new Range(128, 255), True, 255) ' Find the convex envelope of the particles in i. ' Store the result in j. Algorithms.ConvexHull (i, j)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Danielsson(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Creates a very accurate distance map based on the Danielsson distance algorithm. The method encodes the pixel value of a particle as a function of the distance of the pixel from the particle perimeter. For a faster but less precise algorithm, use the method.
member.param: The image that the method uses to compute the distance map.
The image that contains the result.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8 and I16 images. This method modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least one pixel wide.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.WindowForms
' This example assumes you have two viewers on your form. Dim i As New VisionImage
' Threshold the image in Viewer1 and store the results in i. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, i, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
' Create a distance map of i using the Danielsson algorithm. ' Store the result in the image in Viewer2. Algorithms.Danielsson (i, imageViewer2.Image)
' View the results on Viewer2 using a binary palette. imageViewer2.Palette.Type = PaletteType.Binary

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.FindCircles(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Separates overlapping circular objects and classifies them based on their radius, surface area, and perimeter. Starting from a binary image, this method finds the radius and center of the circular objects even when multiple circular objects overlap. In addition, this method can trace the circles in the destination image. It constructs and uses a Danielsson distance map to determine the radius of each object.
member.param: The image to process.
The resulting image.
member.returns: A collection of objects containing the measurements for circles found.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8 images. This method operates on circles with radii less than or equal to 256 pixels.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.FindCircles(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Range)
member.summary: Separates overlapping circular objects and classifies them based on their radius, surface area, and perimeter. Starting from a binary image, this method finds the radius and center of the circular objects even when multiple circular objects overlap. In addition, this method can trace the circles in the destination image. It constructs and uses a Danielsson distance map to determine the radius of each object.
member.param: The image to process.
The resulting image.

The minimum and maximum values for the radius, in pixels, of the circle to detect. Circles with radii outside of this value do not appear in the destination image or in the collection of CircleReports. The default value is (1, 10).
member.returns: A collection of objects containing the measurements for circles found.
member.remarks: Use this method with U8 images. This method operates on circles with radii less than or equal to 256 pixels.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports System.Collections.ObjectModel
'This example requires you to have a ListBox named List1 on the form. Dim i As New VisionImage Dim j As New Integer
'Threshold the image in Viewer1 inplace. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
'Separate and classify circular objects in the image in Viewer1 'and store the results in i Dim Reports As Collection(Of CircleReport) = Algorithms.FindCircles (imageViewer1.Image, i, New Range(1, 100))
'Display the areas in the ListBox List1.Items.Clear() For Each Report As CircleReport In Reports List1.Items.Add(Report.Area) Next

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Label(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Labels the particles in a binary image by applying a unique value to all pixels within a particle. This value is encoded in 8 or 16 bits, depending on the image type. The method can label 255 particles in an 8-bit image and 65,535 particles in a 16-bit image.
member.param: The source image.
The resulting image.
member.returns: The number of particles that the method detected.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Label(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Connectivity)
member.summary: Labels the particles in a binary image by applying a unique value to all pixels within a particle. This value is encoded in 8 or 16 bits, depending on the image type. The method can label 255 particles in an 8-bit image and 65,535 particles in a 16-bit image.
member.param: The source image. The labeling process modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least one pixel wide if you use Connectivity4 or two pixels wide if you use Connectivity8.
The resulting image.

Set this parameter to Connectivity8 to use connectivity-8 to determine whether particles are touching. Set this parameter to Connectivity4 to use connectivity-4 to determine whether particles are touching. The default is Connectivity8. Refer to the NI Vision Concepts Help for more information about connectivity.
member.returns: The number of particles that the method detected.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.WindowsForms
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Threshold the image in Viewer1 Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
'Label the image in Viewer1 and store the result in i Algorithms.Label (imageViewer1.Image, i)
'Label the image in Viewer1 using Connectivity4 'and store the result in the image in Viewer2. 'View the results in Viewer2 using a binary palette Algorithms.Label (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer2.Image, Connectivity.Connectivity4) imageViewer2.Palette.Type = PaletteType.Binary

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Morphology(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.MorphologyMethod)
member.summary: Applies morphological transformations to binary images.
member.param: The image on which the method performs the morphological operations.
The resulting image.
The type of morphological transformation to use.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
The source and destination images must be U8 images.
The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.
This method is optimized for MMX.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Morphology(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.MorphologyMethod,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.StructuringElement)
member.summary: Applies morphological transformations to binary images.
member.param: The image on which the method performs the morphological operations.
The resulting image.
The type of morphological transformation to use.
The structuring element used in the operation. Pass null or Nothing for this parameter if you do not want a custom structuring element.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
The source and destination images must be U8 images.
The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.
This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.WindowsForms
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Threshold the image in Viewer1 to make it a binary image. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range (128, 255), True, 255)
'Perform a POpen operation on the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i. Algorithms.Morphology (imageViewer1.Image, i, MorphologyMethod.POpen)
'Display the result in Viewer2 using a binary palette. imageViewer2.Palette.Type = PaletteType.Binary

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Segmentation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Starting from a labeled image, calculates the zones of influence between particles. Each labeled particle dilates/grows until the particles reach their neighbors, at which time this growth is stopped. Before calling this method, you must label the particles with the method.
member.param: The image to segment.
The destination image.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
Use this method with U8 and I16 images.
The segmentation modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least one pixel wide.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.WindowsForms
Dim i As New VisionImage 'Threshold the image in Viewer1. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
'Label the image in Viewer1 and store the result in i. Algorithms.Label (imageViewer1.Image, i)
'Segment the image in i. 'Do the operation in-place (Store the result in i). Algorithms.Segmentation (i, i)
'View i in Viewer2 using a binary palette. imageViewer2.Attach (i) imageViewer2.Palette.Type = PaletteType.Binary

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Separation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Separates touching particles, particularly small isthmuses found between particles. After performing the erosion, the algorithm reconstructs the image.
member.param: The image containing particles to separate.
The resulting image.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
All source and destination images must be U8 images.
The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Separation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32)
member.summary: Separates touching particles, particularly small isthmuses found between particles. This method performs n erosions (n = erosions), and then reconstructs the final image based on the results of the erosion. If an existing isthmus is broken or removed during the erosion process, the particles are reconstructed without the isthmus. The reconstructed particles, however, have the same size as the initial particles except that they are separated. If no isthmus is broken during the erosion process, the particles are reconstructed as they were initially found, and no change is made.
member.param: The image containing particles to separate.
The resulting image.
The number of erosions to perform. The default is 1.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
All source and destination images must be U8 images.
The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Separation(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,System.Int32,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.StructuringElement)
member.summary: Separates touching particles, particularly small isthmuses found between particles. This method performs n erosions (n = erosions), and then reconstructs the final image based on the results of the erosion. If an existing isthmus is broken or removed during the erosion process, the particles are reconstructed without the isthmus. The reconstructed particles, however, have the same size as the initial particles except that they are separated. If no isthmus is broken during the erosion process, the particles are reconstructed as they were initially found, and no change is made.
member.param: The image containing particles to separate.
The resulting image.
The number of erosions to perform. The default is 1.
The structuring element applied to the image. The method applies a 3 x 3 structuring element if you pass null or Nothing for this parameter.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
All source and destination images must be U8 images.
The source image for a morphological transformation must have been created with a border capable of supporting the size of the structuring element. A 3 x 3 structuring element requires a minimal border of 1, a 5 x 5 structuring element requires a minimal border of 2, and so on. The border size of the destination image is not important.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Threshold the image in Viewer1 to make it a binary image. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
'Separate the particles in the image on Viewer1. Algorithms.Separation (imageViewer1.Image, i)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Distance(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Creates a distance map. The method encodes the pixel value of a particle as a function of the distance of the pixel from the particle border. For a more precise but slower algorithm, use the method.
member.param: The image that the method uses to compute the distance map.
The resulting image.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. All images must be U8 images. The method modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least half as large as the larger of the structuring element dimensions.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Distance(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.StructuringElement)
member.summary: Creates a distance map. The method encodes the pixel value of a particle as a function of the distance of the pixel from the particle border. For a more precise but slower algorithm, use the method.
member.param: The image that the method uses to compute the distance map.
The resulting image.

Describes the structuring element applied to the image. The method uses a 3 x 3 structuring element if you do not set this parameter. For more information on structuring elements, refer to the NI Vision Concepts Help.
member.remarks: This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method. All images must be U8 images. The method modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least half as large as the larger of the structuring element dimensions.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.WindowsForms
Dim i As New VisionImage Dim structuringElement As New StructuringElement
' Threshold the image in Viewer1 and store the results in i. Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, i, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
' Create a distance map of i. ' Store the result in the image in Viewer2. Algorithms.Distance (i, imageViewer2.Image)
' View the results on Viewer2 using a binary palette. imageViewer2.Palette.Type = PaletteType.Binary

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Skeleton(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Starting from a binary image, calculates the skeletons of the particles within an image or the lines delineating the zones of influence of the objects (skeleton of an inverse image).
member.param: The image whose skeleton the method derives.
The resulting image.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
Use this method with U8 images.
The calculation modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least one pixel wide.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Skeleton(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.SkeletonMethod)
member.summary: Starting from a binary image, calculates the skeletons of the particles within an image or the lines delineating the zones of influence of the objects (skeleton of an inverse image).
member.param: The image whose skeleton the method derives.
The resulting image.
The method to calculate the skeleton. The default is L.
member.remarks:
This method modifies the source image. If you need the original source image, create a copy of the image using the method before using this method.
Use this method with U8 images.
The calculation modifies the border of the source image. The border must be at least one pixel wide.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
'Threshold the image in Viewer1 Algorithms.Threshold (imageViewer1.Image, imageViewer1.Image, New Range(128, 255), True, 255)
'Perform a skeleton on the image in Viewer1. 'Store the result in i. Algorithms.Skeleton (imageViewer1.Image, i, SkeletonMethod.Inverse)
imageViewer2.Attach (i)

member.summary: Applies morphological reconstruction to gray scale images.
member.param: The image on which the method performs the morphological operation.
The resulting image.
Points is an array of point-coordinates in a source image that define where the reconstruction starts.
The type of morphological reconstruction procedure to use dilate or erode.
ROI Descriptor defines the region of interest (ROI) within which the morphological reconstruction is performed.

remarks.para: Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.
source, destination and marker images must be the same type.
Marker is specified either though the array of points or using the marker image. If none or both of them are specified then and error is thrown.

member.summary: Applies morphological reconstruction to gray scale images.
member.param: The image on which the method performs the morphological operation.
The resulting image.
Points is an array of point-coordinates in a source image that define where the reconstruction starts.
The type of morphological reconstruction procedure to use dilate or erode.
Describes the structuring element applied to the image. The default is 3 x 3.
ROI Descriptor defines the region of interest (ROI) within which the morphological reconstruction is performed.

remarks.para: Use this method with U8, I16, and Single images.
source, destination and marker images must be the same type.
Marker is specified either though the array of points or using the marker image. If none or both of them are specified then and error is thrown.

A structuring element must have odd-sized dimensions so that it contains a central pixel. If one of the dimensions for the structuring element is even, then function throws an error. The processing speed is correlated with the size of the structuring element. For example, a 3 x 3 structuring element processes nine pixels, and a 5 × 5 structuring element processes 25 pixels.

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.And(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Computes a bitwise AND or a bitwise NAND between two images.
member.param: The input image.
The second input image.
The resulting image.
member.remarks: Use this method with image types U8, I16, Rgb32, and Hsl32. This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
' And image i with the image in imageViewer1. ' Do the operation inplace (store the result in i) Algorithms.And(imageViewer1.Image, i, i)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.And(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.PixelValue,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage)
member.summary: Computes a bitwise AND between an image and a constant.
member.param: The input image.
The pixel value.
The resulting image.
member.remarks: Use this method with image types U8, I16, Rgb32, and Hsl32. This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage
' And operation between a constant and an image in imageViewer1. ' Store the result in i Algorithms.And(imageViewer1.Image, New PixelValue(1), i)

member.name: M:NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.Algorithms.Compare(NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.VisionImage,NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis.ComparisonFunction)
member.summary: Performs comparison operations between two images.
member.param: The first input image.
The second input image.
The resulting image. It can be one of the source images.
The comparison operator to use.
member.remarks: Use this method with image types U8, I16, and Sgl. All input images must have the same image type. This method is optimized for MMX.

example.code:
Imports NationalInstruments.Vision Imports NationalInstruments.Vision.Analysis
Dim i As New VisionImage ' Compare a constant to an image in Viewer1. ' Store the result in i Algorithms.Compare (imageViewer1.Image, New PixelValue(50), i, ComparisonFunction.ClearEqual) ' Compare image i to the image in Viewer1. ' Do the comparison inplace (store the result in i) Algorithms.Compare (imageViewer1.Image, i, i, ComparisonFunction.ClearGreater)
